bacterial_panicle_blight.description: A bacterial disease affecting rice panicles, especially during hot and humid weather common in Sri Lanka's dry zone. Leads to poor grain development and yield loss.
symptoms: Grains appear discolored (light brown to gray)
Unfilled or partially filled panicles
Foul, rotten odor from infected panicles
Premature drying of panicles
prevention: Use disease-free and certified seeds
Avoid overuse of nitrogen fertilizer
Ensure proper field spacing for air circulation
Rotate crops with non-host plants like pulses
bacterial_panicle_blight.treatment: No effective curative treatment. Focus on prevention through seed treatment and balanced nutrient management.
bacterial_panicle_blight.note: Commonly observed in Anuradhapura and Polonnaruwa during Yala season.

downey_mildew.description: A fungal-like oomycete disease that spreads rapidly in wet, humid conditions typical of Sri Lanka's wet zone and intermediate zones.
symptoms: Yellowish streaks on young leaves
White, downy fungal growth on underside of leaves
Stunted plant growth
Reduced tillering
factors: Prolonged leaf wetness from rain or fog
prevention: Improve field drainage
Avoid excessive irrigation
Grow resistant varieties such as Bg 300, Bg 358
Destroy infected seedlings in nurseries
downey_mildew.treatment: Apply protective fungicides like Mancozeb or Metalaxyl in early stages if outbreak is detected.
downey_mildew.note: Frequently seen in nursery beds in Kandy and Nuwara Eliya during rainy periods.

dead_heart.description: Not a disease but a pest infestation. A major issue in Sri Lankan paddy fields where the stem borer larvae tunnel into the stem, killing the central shoot.
symptoms: Central leaf whorl dries up and turns brown
No panicle emerges from affected tillers
Hollow stems with larval frass inside
factors: Weedy fields providing shelter for pests
prevention: Drain fields periodically to disrupt larval development
Use light traps to reduce adult moth populations
Encourage natural predators like spiders and wasps
dead_heart.treatment: Apply selective insecticides like Cartap hydrochloride or Chlorantraniliprole only when infestation exceeds economic threshold.
dead_heart.note: Widespread during Maha season in Kurunegala and Puttalam.

bacterial_leaf_blight.description: One of the most destructive bacterial diseases of rice in Sri Lanka, especially in irrigated and lowland areas with flood-prone conditions.
symptoms: V-shaped, yellow-to-brown lesions starting from leaf margins
Lesions expand and merge, causing large blighted areas
Wilting and drying of entire leaves under severe infection
factors: Wounding from wind, rain, or mechanical damage
prevention: Use resistant varieties (e.g., Bg 379-2, Bg 380)
Avoid excessive nitrogen application
Practice alternate wetting and drying (AWD) irrigation
bacterial_leaf_blight.treatment: Spray copper-based bactericides (e.g., Copper oxychloride) at early symptom stage. Remove and destroy severely infected plants.
bacterial_leaf_blight.note: Major problem in Hambantota and Ampara during Yala season after heavy rains.

brown_spot.description: A common fungal disease that affects leaves and grains, often associated with nutrient imbalance, particularly low silicon or potassium.
symptoms: Small, circular brown spots with dark borders on leaves
Spots may have light centers
Severe infections cause leaf blight and poor grain filling
prevention: Apply balanced fertilizers with emphasis on potassium and silicon
Use quality seed and maintain healthy seedlings
Ensure good air movement in field
brown_spot.treatment: Foliar spray with Mancozeb or Propiconazole if disease pressure is high. Most effective when applied at early boot stage.
brown_spot.note: Often observed in poorly managed fields across the dry zone.

normal.description: No signs of disease, pests, or nutrient deficiency. Plant shows vigorous growth and green color with proper development.
symptoms: Vibrant green leaves with no discoloration
Normal plant height and tillering
Healthy root system
Proper panicle development and grain filling
prevention: Maintain proper water management
Follow recommended fertilizer schedule
Monitor regularly for early signs of pests or disease
Use certified seeds and maintain field hygiene
normal.treatment: No treatment needed. Continue with good agricultural practices to maintain plant health.
normal.note: Well-managed fields with good agronomic practices typically show this condition across all rice-growing regions of Sri Lanka.

hispa.description: An insect pest that feeds on leaf tissue, reducing photosynthesis. Common in transplanted rice fields during warm months.
symptoms: Silvery-white scraping damage on upper leaf surface
Leaves appear thread-like or torn
Severe infestations cause stunted growth and yield loss
factors: Warm, dry weather followed by rain
prevention: Avoid dense transplanting
Flood fields briefly to drown larvae
Hand-pick and destroy adults in small farms
hispa.treatment: Use insecticides like Cartap hydrochloride or Chlorpyrifos only when necessary. Avoid spraying during flowering to protect pollinators.
hispa.note: Frequent in rice fields of Gampaha and Colombo districts.

tungro.caused_by: Tungro viruses (RTBV & RTSV), transmitted by green leafhoppers
tungro.description: A viral disease that causes severe stunting and yield loss. Cannot be cured once a plant is infected.
symptoms: Plants are stunted with reduced tillering
Leaves turn orange-yellow from tip downwards
Reduced panicle formation and grain yield
factors: Nearby infected fields or weed hosts
prevention: Use resistant varieties like Bg 379-2 or At 362
Control leafhoppers using yellow sticky traps or neem-based sprays
Remove infected plants immediately
tungro.treatment: No cure available. Prevention is critical.
tungro.note: Outbreaks often linked to continuous cropping without fallow in Monaragala.

blast.description: One of the most devastating diseases of rice worldwide and a recurring issue in Sri Lanka, especially in upland and rainfed ecosystems.
symptoms: Diamond-shaped or spindle-shaped grayish lesions with dark borders on leaves
Neck blast causes panicle breakage and complete grain loss
Lesions may coalesce and kill entire leaves
prevention: Grow resistant varieties (e.g., Bg 300, Bg 358)
Avoid excessive nitrogen
Practice crop rotation and remove crop residue
blast.treatment: Apply fungicides like Tricyclazole or Propiconazole at early boot stage if symptoms are detected.
blast.note: Major threat in Nuwara Eliya and Badulla during Yala season.

bacterial_leaf_streak.description: A bacterial disease that causes linear streaks on leaves, often confused with leaf blight. Spreads through water splash and wind-driven rain.
symptoms: Water-soaked streaks on leaves that turn brown
Long, narrow streaks between veins
Leaves may tear easily under wind or rain
prevention: Use certified, disease-free seeds
Avoid excessive nitrogen
Allow field drying between irrigations
bacterial_leaf_streak.treatment: Copper-based sprays (e.g., Copper oxychloride) can reduce spread if applied early.
bacterial_leaf_streak.note: Increasingly reported in wet zone districts like Ratnapura and Kalutara.
